metadata.sermon_title: What a Difference a Week Makes!
metadata.bible_text: Matthew 2:13-23 (The Flight to Egypt and the Slaughter of the Innocents)
metadata.sermon_start_end: A week is a long time. The week from Christmas to the next Sunday is a very long time, filled with tension, exhaustion, and extra business. Oh, I do not mean your week. I mean the week that has passed for the characters in the Bethlehem story [...] A new beginning that persists in vulnerable but resilient ways.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon focuses on the narrative shift between the birth and the flight to Egypt. It identifies the specific 'drastic change' in the characters. However, it leans heavily on a thematic contrast (innocence vs. reality) rather than uncovering what is unique to Matthew 2 that exists *nowhere else*. The focus on 'the angel' as a character is specific, but the 'overplus of power' is a general theological truth.
quotes: It is that startling, drastic change in the characters that I want you to focus on
The characters, like us, seem to have departed their trusting innocence and moved into real life.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the unique Matthean emphasis on the fulfillment of prophecy (Hosea, Jeremiah) which is central to this specific text but ignored here in favor of a psychological 'week later' framing.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is thin. While it mentions Herod replicating Pharaoh and the Exodus, it lacks the depth of Hebrew/Greek scholarship Dekker demands. There is no engagement with the historical-critical problems of the text or the specific theology of Matthew. It treats the characters more as literary archetypes than historical-theological figures.
quotes: Herod replicates the old way of Pharaoh back in the book of Exodus
The church’s lectionary suggestion skips over these verses; too cruel.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific socio-political context of the Herodian dynasty and the theological necessity of the 'Nazarene' designation to ground the sermon in scholarly exposition.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is semi-concrete regarding the 'university campus' and 'reasons of state,' but it often retreats into generalities about 'brutalizing forces' and 'innocent love.' It lacks the sharp, specific cultural philosophy Dekker expects.
quotes: It is an odd and awkward assignment to speak of angels on a university campus
The Bible brings us cold faced to the power of evil that takes socio-political, military, economic form.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'socio-political form' to name specific contemporary 'Herods' or 'slaughters' relevant to the congregation's immediate world to avoid 'general truths'.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon succeeds well in mixing exposition and application. The preacher moves between the biblical character and the hearer's reality within the same paragraphs, drawing the hearer into the text's movement.
quotes: The characters, like us, seem to have departed their trusting innocence
In our tired, frightened status quo... Jesus scares us as much as he threatens Herod.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'exposition' side of the mix is more substantively exegetical so the hearer is drawn into the *text* rather than just a *narrative idea*.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (Herod's rage, our cynicism) and Redemption (the angel's intervention, Christ's vulnerability) are present. Gratitude is less explicit but implied in the 'new beginning.' The sermon correctly identifies misery as 'misery before God' (resistance to God's movement).
quotes: Herod embodies resistance... to the movement of God
God’s protective power keeps vulnerable love at work.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'redemption' aspect feels somewhat detached from the cross (though mentioned) and more focused on a 'wild card' angel; it needs a stronger link to the Spirit-awakened gratitude.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon explicitly calls for a 'decision' and to 'pick a winner.' It highlights the possibility of being lost in the 'resistance' of Herod. It takes the hearer seriously as a responsible being.
quotes: In this conflict (and nowhere else) is where we must live and decide, and pick a winner.
Notice the odds, put your money down, and bet your life.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Clarify the 'eternal' dimension of this choice to fully satisfy Dekker’s requirement for the two ways, as the sermon leans heavily on 'temporal' loss.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the telos, but the sermon spends significant time on the 'angel' as the primary actor of the 'overplus of power.' While it mentions Christ's two natures (vulnerability and power), the 'angel' almost overshadows the 'One Lord'.
quotes: The one Lord who is central in the sermon is Christ. [Implicit]
The power the baby embodies is set in the very face of Herod!
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Re-center the 'overplus of power' more directly in the person of Christ rather than the 'angelic wild card' to ensure Christ is the true telos.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 16.5 minutes (1650 words), the sermon falls short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-minute threshold, providing more biblical-theological substance.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short primarily in its duration and the depth of its original-context exegesis. It relies on a narrative-psychological framework ('what a difference a week makes') rather than a rigorous engagement with the Greek text or Matthean theology. However, it is strong in its refusal to remain romantic, its sharp address of the 'two ways' (the choice between Herod and Jesus), and its effective interwoveness of text and hearer.
strengths: Interwoveness: The preacher successfully avoids the 'lecture-then-moral' structure.
Seriousness of Choice: It confronts the hearer with the necessity of decision (Thesis 6).
Tone: It maintains a sober, non-sentimental view of the 'slaughter of the innocents'.
weaknesses: Insufficient Length: At ~16 minutes, it lacks the breadth Miskotte/Dekker demand.
Exegetical Deficit: Minimal evidence of the 'bicycle mechanic's' technical tools (languages, history).
Thematic Generalization: The 'angel' becomes a metaphor for general 'newness' rather than a specific proclamatory word from the text.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate proclamatory speech that approaches the definition of a sermon but lacks the necessary exegetical weight and duration to fully satisfy Dekker's criteria.
